required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Preoperative Antibiotics for Carpal Tunnel Release Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Endoscopic Carpal Tunnel Release, Infection Incidence, and Prophylactic Antibiotics: Indicated or Kick the Habit?

brief_summary.textblock: This is a clinical trial to determine how effective antibiotics administered prior to endoscopic carpal tunnel release surgery are in preventing surgical site infections.

detailed_description.textblock: Study participants will be randomized to a prophylactic IV antibiotic treatment arm (Vancomycin or Cefazolin) or a placebo IV saline solution. Subjects will be monitored following surgery for surgical site infections.

study_design_info.masking_description: Principal investigator, co-investigators, and participants are blinded to study intervention

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Surgical Site Infection
primary_outcome.description: Definitive diagnosis of infection of surgical site -wounds determined to be infected will be divided into superficial or deep infections and treated according to the standard of care at WellSpan health.

intervention.description: 2-gram dosing for patients <120 kg 3-gram dosing for patients 120 kg or greater

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- High probability (>12 points) on the Carpal Tunnel-6 diagnostic aide
- Recommendation for carpal tunnel release
- Capable of providing informed consent/LAR to act on subject's behalf
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients allergic to both penicillin/cephalosporins and vancomycin
- Patient immobilized with splint or cast
- Unwilling unable to provide informed consent
- Children under the age of 18

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
